explanation: The report is not correct. The four statements of the form (void) param; are the conventional, intentional idiom for marking function parameters as unused in C. They are not vestigial code accidentally left in the program; they document intent and suppress compiler warnings. MISRA Rule 2.2 bans truly dead operations that are accidental (code whose execution has no purpose and whose removal would have no plausible effect on the project). The cast-to-void idiom has a purpose (it affects compilation diagnostics and documents intent) and is an accepted practice to handle unused parameters; MISRA toolchains and guidance typically treat this idiom as legitimate (or, if policy requires, as a documented deviation). The supplied runtime logging test does not exercise generate_page, so it gives no evidence that those statements are unreachable or accidental. If you want to avoid even the appearance of an issue, use a compiler attribute (e.g. unused) or a project-wide macro for marking unused parameters, or remove/unname parameters where the function signature permits it.
